overview: Income Tax is a tax on income - find out about what it is, tax codes, how you pay and how to check you're paying the right amount
title: Income Tax

table.body:
Income Tax is a tax on income. Not all income is taxable.  

Taxable income includes:

- earnings from employment
- earnings from self-employment
- most pensions income
- interest on most savings
- rental income
- income paid to you from a trust

You'll never pay tax on some income, including:

- certain benefits
- income from tax exempt accounts
- Working Tax Credit
- premium bond wins

^You can find a list of [taxable and non-taxable income](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/incometax/taxable-income.htm "taxable and non-taxable income"){:rel="external"} on the HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC) website.^

HMRC will give you a tax code that's used to work out how much tax you should be paying if you're employed or pay tax through PAYE (Pay As You Earn).

##Income Tax allowances

Most people in the UK get a 'Personal Allowance' of tax-free income. This is what you can earn each year before you pay tax. 

There are also other allowances, and you're only taxed above a certain level - see the [Income Tax rates and allowances](/income-tax-rates "Income Tax rates and allowances") to find out more.

^There's information about various [tax reliefs](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/incometax/intro-tax-allow.htm "tax reliefs"){:rel="external"} that can reduce your tax bill on the HMRC website.^


*[HMRC]: HM Revenue & Customs
*[PAYE]: Pay As You Earn
table.title: Overview

table.body:
Your tax code is used for calculating how much tax to deduct from your pay or pension. It's worked out by HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC) and given to your employer or pension provider.

^Tax codes are usually made up of numbers and a letter - [find out what your tax code means.](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/incometax/codes-basics.htm "find out what your tax code means"){:rel="external"}^

Your tax code is on:

- your payslip
- your P45 
- your P60
- your [PAYE Coding Notice](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/incometax/understand-p2.htm "PAYE Coding Notice"){:rel="external"}

If you're starting your first job and don't have a P45, your employer will give you a P46 form to fill out and sign. HMRC will then issue your tax code.

##How tax codes are worked out

s1. Your tax allowances are added up. 
s2. Income you've not paid tax on (eg untaxed interest or part-time earnings) and any taxable employment benefits are added up.
s3. The income you've not paid tax on is taken away from your allowances. What's left is the tax-free income you're allowed in a tax year.
s4. This amount is divided by 10 and added to the letter for your circumstances. 

It's important to have the right tax code - you could end up paying too much or too little tax otherwise. You can [report your tax code as wrong](/reporting-your-tax-code-as-wrong "report your tax code as wrong") if it's incorrect.

##Changes that affect your tax code

You need to [tell HMRC](http://search2.hmrc.gov.uk/kbroker/hmrc/contactus/search.ladv?raction=view&fl0=__dsid%3A&sm=0&ha=34&as=1&sf=&sp_scope=hmrc&cs=ISO-8859-1&tx0=49612 "tell HMRC"){:rel="external"} about changes in your circumstances, eg if:

- you get married, form a civil partnership or separate and either of you were born before 6 April 1935
- you start getting a second (or third or more) income
- the amount of untaxed income you get increases or reduces
 
^If you're given a new tax code, HMRC will send you a [PAYE Coding Notice.](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/incometax/understand-p2.htm "PAYE Coding Notice"){:rel="external"}^

##Emergency tax codes

Sometimes your employer or pension provider puts you on an emergency tax code until HMRC has worked out your tax code. When this happens:

- you'll get the basic personal allowance 
- once HMRC has details of your previous income and tax, they'll send the correct tax code
- any overpaid tax will be refunded

*[HMRC]:HM Revenue & Customs 
*[PAYE]:Pay As You Earn
table.title: Tax codes

table.body:
To work out if you're a taxpayer, follow these steps:

s1. Add up all your [taxable income.](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/incometax/taxable-income.htm "taxable income"){:rel="external"}
s2. Work out your [tax-free allowances](/income-tax-rates 'tax-free allowances'). Your Personal Allowance and the Blind Person's Allowance (if applicable) will tell you how much you can earn before you have to pay tax.
s3. Take your tax-free allowances away from your taxable income and:

- if there's anything left, you're a taxpayer and must [contact HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC)](http://search2.hmrc.gov.uk/kbroker/hmrc/contactus/search.ladv?raction=view&fl0=__dsid%3A&sm=0&ha=34&as=1&sf=&sp_scope=hmrc&cs=ISO-8859-1&tx0=49612 'contact HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC)'){:rel="external"}  if you're not already paying tax
- if there's nothing left, you shouldn't be paying tax and may be due a refund

^You can [check if you qualify for a tax refund](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/calcs/stc.htm "check if you qualify for a tax refund"){:rel="external"} and claim online.^

*[HMRC]:HM Revenue & Customs
table.title: Should you be paying Income Tax?

table.body:
Income Tax is collected in different ways, which include:

- PAYE (Pay As You Earn) - your employer or pension provider deducts Income Tax from your wages or pension throughout the year
- Self Assessment - where you tell HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC) about your income if your situation is more complicated (eg you're self-employed) - you can [fill in your tax Self Assessment](/file-your-self-assessment-tax-return 'fill in your tax Self Assessment') online
- deductions from bank/building society interest before it's paid to you
- one-off payments - [contact HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC)](http://search2.hmrc.gov.uk/kbroker/hmrc/contactus/search.ladv?sr=0&as=1&cs=ISO-8859-1&sc=hmrc&sf=&sm=0&nh=50&ha=34&tx0=49612&fl0=__dsid:&tx1=2037&raction=view 'contact HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC)'){:rel="external"} for more information

If you have untaxed income (eg rental or savings income) and you already pay some tax through PAYE, you may be able to add it to your employment or pension income and pay tax on it through your tax code. 

There's more information about [how other income is taxed](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/incometax/non-paye-income.htm "how other income is taxed"){:rel="external"} on the HMRC website. 


*[PAYE]: Pay As You Earn
*[HMRC]: HM Revenue & Customs
table.title: How you pay Income Tax

table.body:
To find out if you're paying the right tax, use the [tax checker](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/calcs/stc.htm 'HMRC's tax checker'){:rel="external"} on the HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC) website. 

You need to be:

- under 65
- a basic or higher rate tax payer
- getting the basic Personal Allowance

You can't use the tax checker if:

- you're entitled to claim [Married Couple's Allowance](/married-couples-allowance "Married Couple's Allowance")
- you're 65 or over and get age-related allowances
- your income is over £100,000
- you have other taxable income (eg from dividends and trusts)
- you get taxable State benefits
- you're self-employed

You also need details of:

- your total earnings for the tax year before tax was taken off
- the total tax paid on your earnings
- the interest from any savings after tax was taken off
- the total tax you paid on savings
- the total amount of any Gift Aid donations you've made

The tax checker will give you an estimate.

*[HMRC]: HM Revenue & Customs
table.title: Check you're paying the right amount
